review.title: Parametric Prediction from Parametric Agents
review.abstract: We consider a problem of prediction based on opinions elicited from heterogeneous rational agents with private information. Making an accurate prediction with a minimal cost requires a joint design of the incentive mechanism and the prediction algorithm. Such a problem lies at the nexus of statistical learning theory and game theory, and arises in many domains such as consumer surveys and mobile crowdsourcing. In order to elicit heterogeneous agents' private information and incentivize agents with different capabilities to act in the principal's best interest, we design an optimal joint incentive mechanism and prediction algorithm called COPE (COst and Prediction Elicitation), the analysis of which offers several valuable engineering insights. First, when the costs incurred by the agents are linear in the exerted effort, COPE corresponds to a "crowd contending" mechanism, where the principal only employs the agent with the highest capability. Second, when the costs are quadratic, COPE corresponds to a "crowd-sourcing" mechanism that employs multiple agents with different capabilities at the same time. Numerical simulations show that COPE improves the principal's profit and the network profit significantly (larger than 30% in our simulations), comparing to those mechanisms that assume all agents have equal capabilities.

sections.heading: 1.2. Results and Contributions
sections.text: We focus on the interactions between a principal and multiple agents and design an appropriate incentive mechanism to facilitate the parametric prediction process. Specifically, we design a mechanism we call "COPE" (which stands for "COst and Prediction Elicitation") that jointly optimizes the payment of the principle to agents and the prediction error that arises. COPE provides a systematic way for the principle to motivate all participating agents to truthfully report their estimates and make appropriate efforts based on their respective capabilities. We summarize our key findings and key contributions as follows: • Theoretical Importance: We relax several critical assumptions common in the thermal literature, i.e. the costs incurred by the agents are known to the principle, not known to the agents.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text: We study the parametric prediction market using information asymmetry. In order to elicit the truthful information of the participating agents and exploit the heterogeneity of the agents, we propose the mechanism COPE, which ensures that the agents execute the effort desired by the client and report their true observations. Our analysis shows that under the Gaussian estimate noise scenario, it is optimal for the client to recruit several agents to complete the task. We also present the general form of COPE, which is optimal for a variety of settings (e.g. general cost function and sound distribution). In this work, we have focused on the parametric setting, in which the main persons parameterise the parameters (e.g. the winner of an election), where the value can be observed.
